The hydrogenation of furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and 5-methylfurfural over platinum and palladium catalysts based on porous aromatic frameworks Andrei Dubiniak Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ Leonid Kulikov Writing – review & editing Visualization a Sergey Egazar`yants Visualization Conceptualization a Anton Maximov Methodology Formal analysis a b Eduard Karakhanov Supervision a a Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis, Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow 119991, Russia Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis, Lomonosov Moscow State University Moscow 119991 Russia Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis, Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow, Russia 119991 b Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis RAS, Moscow 119991, Russia Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis RAS Moscow 119991 Russia Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis RAS, Moscow, Russia 119991 ⁎ Correspondence to: Lomonosov Moscow State University, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis, 1-3 Leninskiye Gory, Moscow 119991, Russia. Lomonosov Moscow State University, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis 1-3 Leninskiye Gory Moscow 119991 Russia Platinum and palladium catalysts supported on two types of porous aromatic frameworks, PAF-30 and PAF-30-NH2 (modified with amino groups), were examined in furfural hydrogenation. The influence of temperature, reaction time and solvent on selectivity and activity of the catalysts was investigated. Using isopropanol as solvent and conducting experiments at 40 ℃ led to sufficient decrease of side products yields. According to TEM Pt-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalysts are characterized with uniform particles distribution on support. Elemental analysis shows a difference in palladium content between Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2: 4.6 % and 6.8 % respectively. Whereas platinum catalysts have both 5.4 % of metal. Catalyst Pt-PAF-30 was highly selective to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (83 % yield), whereas the catalyst Pd-PAF-30-NH2 exhibited unusually high selectivity towards tetrahydrofurfural (77 % yield). All studied catalysts were also tested in the hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and 5-methylfurfural, in these experiments up to 20 % yield of 1-hydroxy-4-hexen-2-one was observed. Graphical Abstract Keywords Porous aromatic frameworks Palladium Platinum Nanoparticles Furfural 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 5-methylfurfural Hydrogenation Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays researchers and chemical industries seek for sustainable processes aimed at production of chemicals that can be converted into high value-added products. Lignocellulosic biomass, produced as a waste of wood and paper industry, is a promising source of bio-based platform molecules [1–3]. These include furfural (FA), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), which are formed during carbohydrates conversion [4–7]. They can be transformed into numerous compounds that are used as solvents, fuel additives, monomers for drugs and polymers [8,9]. Thus, the products of furfural hydrogenation include furfuryl alcohol (FAL), 1,2- and 1,5-pentanediols (1,2 and 1,5-PDOL), furan, tetrahydrofuran (THF), tetrahydrofurfural (THFA), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFAL) and cyclopentanone (CPONE) [10–14]. 5-HMF and 5-MF hydrogenation products are 2,5-furandimethanol (DHMF), 5-(hydroxymethyl)-tetrahydrofurfural (HMTHF), 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran (BHMTHF), 5-methyl-2-furanmethanol (MHMF), 5-methyltetrahydro-2-furanmethanol (MHMTHF), 1,2-hexanediol (1,2-HDOL), 2,5-dimethyltetrahydrofuran (DMTHF) and 5-methyltetrahydrofurfural (5-MTHF) [15–17]. Developing new suitable catalytic systems and studying new ways of furanic compounds hydrogenation remains an actual scientific and practical task. Most promising catalysts for FA and 5-HMF hydrogenation are platinum group metals, such as Pt, Pd and Ru [10,15,18,19]. Comparing to non-noble metals, they are characterized with higher activity at milder reaction conditions [20,21]. Palladium catalysts have been reported to be highly selective to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, since palladium is able to hydrogenate simultaneously double bonds and carbonyl group [23,24]. Platinum catalysts, in contrast, favors the formation of furfuryl alcohol and 2-methylfuran [25–27]. Products distribution depends not only on active phase nature, but on support properties: its interaction with metal can significantly change catalyst performance. For example, authors [28] report that palladium immobilized on layered double hydroxides could efficiently catalyze the selective hydrogenation of FA to THFA and HMF to HMTHF in water media. It is stated that water prohibited the hydrogenation of CO group, and the special nature of LDH-MgAl-NO3 prevented hydrogenation of CO group on the support by the hydrogen spillover, thereby furfural undergoes selective ring-hydrogenation on described catalyst. Tao Tong et al. report direct hydrogenolysis of furfural to 1,2-pentanediol and 5-HMF to 1,2,6-hexanetriol on Pt/CeO2 [29]. Despite CO group hydrogenation, this catalyst enhances ring opening and double bonds hydrogenation, which is, as reported previously, less typical for platinum catalysts for furfural hydrogenation [10]. Thus, it is worth developing new catalyst supports to open ways of furan derivatives hydrogenation towards fine chemicals. Organic polymers, in particular porous aromatic frameworks (PAFs), are promising materials for design heterogenous catalysts. PAFs are polymeric structures consisting of aromatic rings linked by carbon-carbon bonds, they possess a regular structure and a large surface area [30]. The advantages of PAFs include high chemical and thermal stability, as well as the ability to modify their structure with various functional groups using simple synthesis methods [31–33]. Herein we report platinum and palladium catalysts based on porous aromatic frameworks for furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and 5-methylfurfural hydrogenation. Two types of supports were used: PAF-30 and PAF-30-NH2, the porous aromatic framework modified with amino groups. Our work focuses on influence of catalyst properties on hydrogenation and reaction conditions effect (temperature, time, solvent). Hydrogenation of 5-HMF and 5-MF was evaluated under optimized reaction conditions to study the difference in substrates properties. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Following reagents were used in current work: furfural (ABCR, 98 %), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (Macklin, 97 %), 5-methylfurfural (Aldrich, 99 %), trifluoroacetic acid (Component-reactive, pure), nitric acid (Reakhim, pure), tin (II) chloride dihydrate (Reakhim, pure), sodium hydroxide (Reakhim, pure), palladium (II) acetate (Aldrich, 99.9 %), tetraammineplatinum (II) chloride hydrate (Aldrich, 98 %), sodium borohydride (Aldrich, 98 %), ethanol (IREA 2000, purum p.a.), dichloromethane (Component-reactive, pure), tetrahydrofuran (Component-reactive, pure), isopropanol (Component-reactive, cp grade). 2.2 Synthesis of materials and catalysts PAF-30 was synthesized using the method described previously [34]. 2.3 Synthesis of PAF-30-NH2 Trifluoroacetic acid (50 mL) was placed in a 100 mL single-neck round bottomed flask, equipped with a stir bar and a reflux condenser, and cooled to 0℃ by water-ice bath. PAF-30 (1.0 g) was added then into flask and the resulting suspension was stirred for 10 minutes, and then fuming HNO3 (300 µL) was added dropwise to it. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir at room temperature for 8 hours, then obtained suspension was poured into cold water. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water (2×50 mL) and ethanol (2×50 mL) and dried under vacuum for 6 hours. PAF-30-NO2 (0.95 g), THF (200 mL) and tin (II) chloride dihydrate (15 g) were placed in a 250 mL single-neck round bottomed flask, equipped with stir bar and reflux condenser. The resulting mixture was stirred for 8 hours and cooled down afterwards. The resulted solid product was filtered and treated 4 times with NaOH solution (10 wt%, 50 mL). After that the precipitate washed with water until neutral pH and then with THF (2×50 mL), and dried under vacuum for 6 hours. 2.4 Synthesis of catalysts Pt-PAF-30 and Pt-PAF-30-NH2 In a 50 mL single-neck round-bottomed flask, equipped with a magnetic stir bar and a reflux condenser 19 mg of [Pt(NH3)4]Cl2 was dissolved in ethanol-water mixture (15 mL, 1:1 vol.). 200 mg of corresponding PAF (PAF-30 or PAF-30-NH2) was added then to the solution, and the resulting suspension was stirred at 60℃ for 24 h. The mixture was cooled to a room temperature, then to 0℃ in an ice bath, and cooled solution of NaBH4 (100 mg) in ethanol-water mixture (10 mL, 1:1) was added dropwise, followed by stirring for another 24 h. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water (2×50 mL) and ethanol (2×50 mL), and dried under vacuum for 6 hours. The resulting product represented a light-grey powder (in case of Pt-PAF-30) or a dirty-green powder (in case of Pt-PAF-30-NH2). 2.5 Synthesis of catalysts Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2 In a 50 mL single-neck round-bottomed flask, equipped with a magnetic stir bar and a reflux condenser 22.3 mg of palladium (II) acetate was dissolved in 15 mL of dichloromethane. 200 mg of corresponding PAF (PAF-30 or PAF-30-NH2) was added then to the resulting solution, and the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After that the solvent was evaporated in a rotary evaporator, and the resulting material was resuspended in 4 mL of methanol and cooled in an ice bath. Then 6 mL of 0.12 M solution of sodium borohydride in water-methanol mixture (1:1 vol.) was added dropwise to the suspension, followed by stirring for another 24 h. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water (2×50 mL) and ethanol (2×50 mL), and dried under vacuum for 6 hours. The resulting product represented a light-grey powder (in case of Pd-PAF-30) or a dark-green powder (in case of Pd-PAF-30-NH2). 2.6 Catalytic experiments Hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a steel autoclave equipped with a glass insert tube and a magnetic stirrer anchor. Catalyst (3 mg), furfural (60 µL), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (71 µL) or 5-methylfurfural (72 µL), and solvent (600 µL) were placed in a test tube. The autoclave was sealed and filled with hydrogen to the required pressure (3 MPa). In experiments at temperatures below 100 °C, the temperature was controlled using a water thermostat, and in experiments at temperatures above 100 °C – using a furnace with a controller. After the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled below room temperature and depressurized. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography. In the recycling experiments, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation after the first run and washed with acetone, followed by centrifugation. The process was repeated twice, and the resultant solid was used directly in the next run with the same amount of fresh substrate. Conversion was calculated by changes in the relative areas (S) of substrate and products peaks on chromatograms according to formula: (1) Conv , % = ∑ S products S substrate + ∑ S products × 100 % # Selectivity and yield on each product (i) for each reaction were calculated according to formulae: (2) Sel i , % = S i ∑ S products × 100 % # (3) Yield i , % = Conv , % × Sel i , % 100 % # Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated as the amount of a reacted substrate (in moles) per mole of Pt or Pd per unit of time with the account of catalyst dispersity DM according to the formula: (4) TOF = Conv . * v Substrate t * v Catalyst * D M , # Dispersion values were calculated as DM = 1.112/d for platinum and DM = 0.885/d for palladium, where d is the average particle size obtained by TEM measurements in nm [35]. 2.7 Characterization Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K with a Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, United States). All samples were degassed at 110°C for 6 h before measurement. The surface area (SBET) and average pore width (4 V/A) were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The total pore volume (Vtot) was determined by the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of P/P0 = 0.96. FTIR spectra were registered with a Nicolet IR 200 (Thermo Scientific) employing multiple distortion of the total internal reflection method with Multi-reflection HATR accessories, containing a ZnSe crystal 45° for different wavelengths with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The content of metal in the catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (AES) on an ICPE-9000 spectrometer (SHIMADZU) in Center for Collective Usage «Analytical Center for the Problems of Deep Refining of Oil and Petrochemistry» of A.V. Topchiev Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis, RAS. TEM analysis was carried out on a JEOL JEM-2100/Cs/GIF microscope (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) with a 0.19 nm lattice fringe resolution and an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The processing of the micrographs and the calculation of the average particle size were conducted using the ImageJ software program. The analysis was performed in the center “Materials Science and Metallurgy” of NUST MISiS. XPS spectra of the surface layers were recorded on an OMICRON ESCA + spectrometer (OMICRON, Germany). The pressure in the chamber of the OMICRON ESCA + analyzer was maintained below 8*10^-10 mbar; the radiation source was the Al anode (AlKα 1486.6 eV). The calibration of photoelectron peaks was based on the C1s line with a binding energy of 284.5 eV. Deconvolution of platinum and palladium high-resolution spectra was performed using CasaXPS v. 2.3.19PR1.0 software. Quantitative analysis of the reaction mixture was carried out on an Agilent 6890 G1530A chromatograph (Hewlett Packard, Santa-Clara, CA, United States) equipped with a flame-ionization detector and a DB-WAX column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 μm). Helium was a carrier gas; the analysis was carried out in constant flow mode (1.5 mL/min). Chromatograms were recorded and analyzed on a computer using the HP ChemStation Rev.A.06.01 (403) software. Identification of reaction products was carried out by gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy and performed on a Leco Pegasus® GC-HRT 4D with an Agilent Technologies 7890 gas chromatograph equipped with a second oven and a nonmoving quad-jet dual-stage modulator. The GC column combination consisted of a Rxi-17Sil MS (30 m; 0.25 mm i.d.; 0.25 μm df) and a Rxi-5Sil MS in the second oven (1.65 m; 0.1 mm i. d.; 0.1 μm df). The second column was connected by an uncoated deactivated capillary both to TOFMS (2.95 m; 0.18 mm i.d.) and FID (1.4 m; 0.25 mm i.d.). The system was used in 1D GC mode for GCxGC setup with a parallel detection by TOFMS and FID. Chromatographic and mass spectrometric conditions are listed in Table 1. Data acquisition and processing were carried out using ChromaTOF™ version 5.32 software (Leco Corporation). The structure of the components was determined by analyzing the mass spectra using the NIST v.2.3 library dated May 4, 2017. The analysis was carried out using equipment purchased with the support of the Moscow University Development Program. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports PAF-30 and PAF-30-NH2 Porous aromatic framework PAF-30 was synthesized from tetrakis-(p-bromophenyl)methane and 4,4′-biphenyldiboronic acid by Suzuki cross-coupling reaction [36]. Modification of PAF-30 with amino groups was carried out through its nitration with the mixture of nitric and trifluoroacetic acids followed by reduction with tin (II) chloride dihydrate in THF [37] ( Fig. 1). Porous structure of the materials was studied by low temperature adsorption-desorption of nitrogen ( Table 2, Fig. 2). Isotherms show a sharp increase at low relative pressures (P/P0 = 0–0.05), indicating the filling of micropores. The presence of mesopores was indicated by a rise of adsorption curve in the range of P/P0 = 0.2–0.9 and hysteresis loop between the adsorption and desorption curves. Modification of PAF-30 with amino-groups led to a decrease in the specific surface area and pore volume. PAF-30 and PAF-30-NH2 materials were characterized by FTIR analysis ( Fig. 3). Absorption band, characteristic for C–Br bond (1076 cm–1), was not observed on the spectra of both frameworks, proving the completeness of cross-coupling reaction. Adsorption bands with maxima at 1600 cm–1, attributed to deformation vibrations of NH2 group, appears in the spectrum of PAF-30-NH2, it should be noted that adsorption bands with maxima at 1390 and 1510 cm–1, attributed to symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching modes of nitro group, are not presented in the spectra, thus, reduction is complete. 3.2 Characterization of platinum and palladium catalysts Noble metal catalysts were synthesized by the immobilization of metal nanoparticles on the surface of frameworks. PAFs were impregnated with the solution of corresponding salt, [Pt(NH3)4]Cl2 and Pd(OAc)2, with further reduction with sodium borohydride ( Fig. 4). It should be noted, that the use of platinum complexes in the impregnation reaction with porous aromatic framework modified with NH2- groups can lead to a better encapsulation due to the interaction between metal complex and functional groups [38]. All catalysts were characterized by means of transmission electron microscopy ( Fig. 5). TEM micrograph of the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst (Fig. 5(A)) shows that metal nanoparticles are evenly distributed on supports surface. NPs size distribution is close to normal (Fig. 5(B)) with average particle size of 4.9 nm. Metal agglomerates on material surface were observed in TEM micrographs, however, their percentage in total number of NPs is lower, comparing to other studied catalysts. Platinum catalyst Pt-PAF-30-NH2 is characterized with gamma particle size distribution (Fig. 5(C, D)), average size of nanoparticles and dispersion is close to Pt-PAF-30. It should be noted, that there are metal agglomerates observed on material surface, micrographs show that the impregnation of platinum on modified framework is not as good as on PAF-30. Metal content in both platinum catalysts is close to theoretical one (5.4 % for both catalysts). Palladium catalyst based on PAF-30 has average NPs size of 9.5 nm, NPs size distribution is close to bimodal (Fig. 5(E, F)). It is worth mentioning that there are large metal particles on surface of porous framework with the size up to 16 nm. Thus, unmodified framework is less suitable for palladium than for platinum in terms of achieving uniform nanoparticles with deep immobilization in pores. Metal content, which is slightly lower than theoretical (4.6 %), confirms this statement. For Pd-PAF-30-NH2 TEM micrographs represents particle size distribution that can be attributed either to gamma or Weibull, average particle size is 6.1 nm, palladium content is 6.8 % (Fig. 5(E, F)). Micrographs show that metal is incapsulated in the pores of support, however, some nanoparticles are located on the surface of material and are bigger than average (up to 10 nm). This catalyst can be compared to Pt-PAF-30 in terms of narrow particles distribution on catalyst support. Pt-PAF-30 XPS spectrum ( Table 3, Fig. 6) contain two set of peaks, attributed to Pt0 (binding energies 71 eV and 74.4 eV) and Pt2+ (binding energies 72 eV and 75.4 eV). It should be noted, that obtained platinum binding energies are lower than for platinum supported on activated carbon and other common inorganic and polymer materials reported in literature [39–42]. Catalyst Pt-PAF-30-NH2 has a shift to lower binding energies compared to Pt-PAF-30, which can be attributed to the effect of electron-donating amino groups [43,44] and the presence of agglomerates on support surface [8]. Palladium catalyst based on PAF-30 framework is also characterized by two set of peaks (Table 3, Fig. 6): Pd0 (binding energies 336 and 341 eV) and Pd2+ (binding energies 337.4 and 342.7 eV). Those values correspond to the palladium catalysts reported in literature [45,46]. Pd-PAF-30-NH2 has lower binding energy compared to Pd-PAF-30. Elemental composition of each catalyst surface determined by XPS is presented in Table 4. The concentration of Pt on surface for Pt-PAF-30 is lower than for Pt-PAF-30-NH2, this fact in addition to TEM data proves that there are more platinum nanoparticles agglomerates on the surface of PAF-30-NH2 material. The opposite trend is observed for palladium catalysts. The content of metal on surface for Pd-PAF-30-NH2 is lower than for unmodified one. Presence of small amounts of tin in Pt-PAF-30-NH2 and Pd- PAF-30-NH2 is attributed to reduction of nitro groups with tin (II) chloride dihydrate. 3.3 Study of catalyst activity It is well known that the composition of furfural hydrogenation products depends significantly on temperature, hydrogen pressure and the solvent used. So, at low temperature (below 50 ℃) the reaction follows the path of hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds with the formation of furfuryl alcohol (FAL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFAL) and tetrahydrofurfuryl aldehyde (THFA) as the main reaction products ( Fig. 7). However, hydrogenation of furfural under the temperature higher than 140℃ leads to the Piancatelli rearrangement and the formation of cyclopentanone (CPONE) and other C5-cycloproducts [53], especially in water media. Another path of furfural conversion at high temperatures is ring-opening reaction that leads to the formation of 4-oxopentanal (4-OPAL) [48]. Various oligomers of furfural and its hydrogenation products can also be formed [49–51], some of which are shown in the Fig. 7. Many researchers focus on solvent effect on hydrogenation [52,53], alcohols and water are found to be the most suitable solvents to reduce the occurrence of side reactions. It should be noted, that alcohols are often considered as hydrogen donors [54], thus solvent can noticeably improve hydrogenation parameters. 3.3.1 Effect of temperature on furfural hydrogenation In order to evaluate the impact of reaction temperature on composition of reaction products, the catalysts were tested in the furfural hydrogenation at three temperature regimes: low-temperature hydrogenation at 40 ℃, moderate-temperature hydrogenation at 90 ℃ and high-temperature hydrogenation at 150 ℃. The results are summarized in the Table 5. All catalysts possess high activity: even at 40℃, furfural was completely hydrogenated at Pt-PAF-30, Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalysts. Notably, both palladium catalysts yield THFA and THFAL as the main products, whereas Pt-PAF-30 gives THFAL, which is unusual for platinum catalysts [10,55]. Also, in the case of the latter catalyst, the reaction products contained a large amount of diols (up to 35 %) formed as a result of opening of the furan ring, and in the case of both palladium catalysts condensation products were formed as side products. Increasing the reaction temperature to 90 ℃ did not lead to a significant change in the composition of the main products, but a slight increase in the content of side products was observed. Despite the furfural conversion on Pt-PAF-30-NH2 was lower – 31 %, high selectivity (up to 95 %) towards furfuryl alcohol (FAL) was achieved. In addition, no side products were detected for this catalyst at either 40 ℃ or 90 ℃. We suggest that FAL formation rate is greater than its ring-opening and/or further hydrogenation rate, thereby, Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst is highly selective to FAL at mild reaction conditions. Further increase of reaction temperature up to 150 ℃ led to decrease in the yields of the products of full hydrogenation, THFA and diols, to 16 % and 10 %, respectively, and increase of the intensity of processes of furan ring opening, rearrangements and deoxygenation. Thus, reaction products on the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst contained 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) and 5-hydroxy-2-pentanone (5-HPONE), with yields of 25 % and 38 %, respectively. This indicates that FAL undergoes dehydration to 2-MF or water-promoted ring opening with the formation of 5-HPONE, which appear to be more favorable on Pt-PAF-30 under hydrothermal conditions than Piancatelli rearrangement [56,57]. Notably, the reaction products almost did not contain 1,4-PDOL formed during the hydrogenation of 5-HPONE. This could mean that the formation of 1,5-PDOL and 1,2-PDOL occurs by hydrogenolysis of the C-O bond on the platinum surface from FAL during the hydrogenation. In contrast to the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst, in the case of the Pt-PAF-30-NH2, Pd-PAF-30, Pd-PAF-30-NH2 the reaction products contained up to 40 % of 4-oxopentanal (4-OPAL) formed by ring-opening reaction, and up to 14 % of the product of its hydrogenation, 5-hydroxy-2-pentanone (5-HPONE). We suggest that 4-OPAL is produced mostly from FAL and to a lesser extent from FA. However, the reaction route leading to 4-OPAL formation is not yet clearly defined, as its production during furfural hydrogenation was reported only by few authors [57–60]. Also, the yield of 4-OPAL is higher on PAF-30-NH2-based catalysts, which could indicate that the presence of amino-groups contributes the ring-opening process with FA. Thus, for Pt-PAF-30-NH2 at 150℃, ring rearrangement processes are more intense than for Pt-PAF-30, and reaction is characterized by the formation of products of Piancatelli rearrangement (namely, cyclopentenone (CPENE), 3-hydroxycyclopentanone (GCPONE) and 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopenten-1-one (GCPENE)) with a total yield of 28 %. A similar effect is also observed for palladium catalysts: in the case of Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst, the reaction products contain more 4-OPAL (41 % vs 17 %) and 5-HPONE (14 % vs 12 %), and less THFAL (14 % vs 35 %). In addition, more oligomers are formed on Pd-PAF-30 catalyst than on Pd-PAF-30-NH2 (14 % vs 9 %), this effect can be explained by difference in metal content: Pd-PAF-30 catalyst has less palladium impregnated by 2.2 % which leads to predominance of oligomerization process over hydrogenation. Thus, the hydrogenation of furfural at low temperatures leads to the formation of a limited number of products depending on the catalyst composition. In the case of both palladium catalysts, the main products are THFA and THFAL, and any influence of amino groups is not observed. In the case of the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst, the main product was THFAL, which is quite unusual, as well as the products of furan ring opening - diols and 5-HPONE. Modification of PAF structure with amino groups allowed to reduce the rates of hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis processes, as a result of which the Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst turned out to be the most selective to FAL. Increasing the reaction temperature to 90 ℃ resulted in accelerated rates of all processes for all catalysts. At further increase of the reaction temperature up to 150 ℃ the intensity of furan ring opening increased significantly, while its hydrogenation - on the contrary, decreased. 3.3.2 Effect of solvent It is reported in literature that solvent can drastically influence activity and selectivity of furfural hydrogenation over various catalytic systems [52,61]. Alcohols are considered promising solvents in FA hydrogenation due to high hydrogen solubility [62] and ability to promote hydrogenation via hydrogen donation [63,64]. Basing on those facts, we tested the catalysts in furfural hydrogenation in ethanol, isopropanol and THF media ( Fig. 8). These solvents have similar dipole moment values (1.6–1.85) but differ in relative polarity decreasing in the series water (1.0) > ethanol (0.654) > isopropanol (0.546) > THF (0.207). The use of a nonpolar solvent for this reaction was not of interest to us because, as a rule, this class of solvents inhibits the hydrogenation reaction [65] and furfural is poorly soluble in alkanes [66]. It can be noted that the composition of reaction products on all catalysts did not change much when the solvent was changed. When the reaction was carried out in water, more ring-opening products were expectedly observed in the reaction products on the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst. Also, complete furfural hydrogenation was observed on the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst in all solvents, but in the case of THF the amount of complete hydrogenation product, THFAL, was lower. Lower activity in THF was also observed for catalyst Pd-PAF-30, which correlates with low metal content in this catalyst. In the case of Pt-PAF-30-NH2, hydrogenation did not take place at all in THF. Full furfural conversion and 83 % selectivity to THFAL was achieved in isopropanol on Pt-PAF-30, and the amount of side reaction products is reduced more than twice comparing to the reaction in H2O media. On the one hand, the effect of alcohols in enhancing the selectivity to THFAL may be due to the absence of water in the reaction medium, which is involved in ring-opening reaction of FAL and the formation of 1,2-PDOL and 5-HPONE [47,57,59,67]. On the other hand, isopropanol can be suitable solvent for THFAL production on the Pt-PAF-30 catalyst due to unique solvent-catalyst-substrate interaction which mainly can be attributed to the solvent intermolecular hydrogen bonding, hydrogen donating ability and solvation effects [52,68–70]. The activity of Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst also increased when alcohols were used as solvents, and in the case of Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst hydrogenation of furfural in i-PrOH media leaded to higher selectivity towards THFA. Thus, THFA yield increased from 29 % to 52 % on Pd-PAF-30 and from 42 % to 77 % on Pd-PAF-30-NH2, and the formation of side products is reduced to insufficient values. The reason for the lower selectivity to THFA in water on palladium catalysts might be attributed to facile CO bond hydrogenation by hydrogen transfer via Grotthuss mechanism, realized between the catalyst surface, adsorbed hydrogen, water and substrate molecules [71]. In contrast, organic solvents favor mostly ring hydrogenation [52,53]. It should be noted that hydrogenation of FA in EtOH did not occur on both palladium catalysts, and only a small yield of acetals was detected in reaction products. Palladium catalysts in ethanol have been reported to poorly adsorb CO group [28] and to promote the formation of acetals rather than FA hydrogenation products more than other common alcohols [70,72]. Also, it is worth mentioning, that all alcohols can produce ethers with furfural and its derivatives [22], however, we haven’t detected them among reaction products on all catalysts in isopropanol. 3.3.3 Reaction kinetics The kinetics of furfural hydrogenation on PAF-based catalysts was studied at 40 ℃ ( Fig. 9). The Pt-PAF-30 shows the highest activity among the studied systems, and the reaction follows the classical path of accumulation of hydrogenation intermediate (FAL) and its further consumption to form THFAL and products of ring-opening reaction (1,2-PDOL, 1,5-PDOL and 5-HPONE). It is worth noting that the concentration curves of THFAL and 1,2-PDOL + 1,5-PDOL + 5-HPONE practically parallel, which confirms the hypothesis of formation of the latter from adsorbed FAL in the course of the hydrogenation. This is also confirmed by the curves reaching a plateau when all the FAL has been consumed. Also, 1,4-pentanediol, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and 1-pentanol formed as side-products. It is worth mentioning, that there are few catalytic systems based on platinum as only active metal that gives tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol as one of the main products under mild reaction conditions [73,74]. This can be related to the features of adsorption of FA molecule on platinum surface and electronic state of the latter. Ring adsorption is conducted via interaction between platinum d-band and π-orbital of furan ring and more electron-dense platinum is reported to favor higher adsorption of FA molecule [75]. In turn, this affects the intensity of further transformation of the formed FAL: when platinum surface is electron- depleted and the adsorption strength is low, FAL molecules are easily desorbed; when moderate – they undergo further hydrogenation to THFAL or undergo hydrogenolysis; finally, when the platinum surface is electron-rich, the interaction force between the platinum surface and the oxygen of the molecule is high, leading to a more intense flow of furan ring opening. Based on XPS results, Pt-PAF-30 and Pt-PAF-30-NH2 are characterized with slightly higher electron density than commercially available Pt/C catalyst [42] (71 eV vs 70.9 eV vs 71.7 eV respectively) which can enhance d-band accessibility, ring adsorption and further FAL conversion [76]. Pt-PAF-30-NH2 shows significantly less activity in the furfural hydrogenation: conversion of 99 % was reached only at 6 hours. The reaction also follows the path of accumulation of FAL and its further consumption. However, after 4 hours of reaction, it is preferentially converted to the products of the furane ring opening reaction, whereas the formation of THFAL is inhibited. This could be explained by specifics of distribution and electron state of platinum nanoparticles. According to micrographs, Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst contain large agglomerates of nanoparticles, which are less active in hydrogenation [77]. Furthermore, as it was discussed before, high electron density of platinum surface platinum favors ring opening reaction [75], and the binding energy of platinum in Pt-PAF-30-NH2 is lower than for Pt-PAF-30. In the case of both palladium catalysts, the reaction proceeds by a different way. The hydrogenation of furfural occurs both on the ring and the carbonyl group, leading to the formation of FAL and THFA as products, respectively. However, FAL remains adsorbed on the palladium surface and is further hydrogenated to THFAL, while THFA is desorbed and practically does not enter into further transformations. These results are in good agreement with literature data, according to which palladium readily hydrogenates furan ring, while the hydrogenation of CO bond is considered to have a higher energy barrier and proceeds slowly [78]. The yields of THFAL and THFA after 5 hours are comparable for Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2, while the yield of side product, mainly oligomers formed from furfural and its derivatives [63], is higher in case of the Pd-PAF-30 catalyst (16 %). As in the case of furfural hydrogenation under various temperatures, the difference in amount of oligomers between palladium catalysts can be explained by different metal content: less metal in Pd-PAF-30 catalyst leads to less hydrogenation rate, whereas oligomerization process is not related to active metal quantity. In order to describe catalysts activity, we calculated turnover frequencies (TOF) for all studied catalysts at 0.5 h reaction time ( Table 6). Pt-PAF-30 is characterized with high turnover frequency, this can be another explanation for large number of various reaction products. As expected, Pt-PAF-30-NH2 has lowest TOF value among studied catalytic systems. Greater TOF value of Pd-PAF-30 comparing to Pd-PAF-30-NH2 can be related to higher formation rate of FAL and oligomers and to significant difference in average particle size. 3.3.4 Recycling tests The stability of all synthesized catalysts was tested in the recycling experiments ( Fig. 10) The Pt-PAF-30 catalyst shows high stability over 5 cycles, and only minor decrease in activity was observed at the 4th cycle, leading to higher FAL formation. The Pd-PAF-30 catalysts also demonstrates good stability: the conversion of furfural remained around 100 % for 3 cycles, after which it decreased by 20 %, which may be due to physical loss of catalyst during recycling. The Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst shows a slight loss of activity, expressed as a decrease in conversion from 28 % to 17 % with no change in product composition. This can be explained by washing out of platinum nanoparticles that are located on the surface of support, or the formation of polymers from FAL (main reaction product in case of Pt-PAF-30-NH2) which blocks active centers [79]. The worst stability demonstrated the Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst: furfural conversion decreased from 100 % to 19 %, and the reaction products after 5 cycles contained mainly products of semi-hydrogenation, FAL and THFA. This also could be due to metal leaching and deactivation of the catalyst by the oligomerization products [80]. To determine the reason for decline in catalysts performance, we characterized catalysts with TEM after 5 reaction cycles ( Fig. 11). Pt-PAF-30 catalyst shows a slight change to lower values in average size of nanoparticles (Fig. 11(A, B)), this can be related to washing out of big NPs. However, micrographs of fresh and used catalyst are practically equal to each other, which correlates with experimental stability of Pt-PAF-30 material. Pt-PAF-30-NH2, in turn, is characterized with larger amount of big nanoparticles up to 13 nm (Fig. 11(C, D)). Thus, loss in activity during recycling can be attributed to metal sintering. Palladium catalyst Pd-PAF-30 shows a shift to higher average NPs size (Fig. 11(E, F)). Since it has similar decline in activity to Pt-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst, we suggest that metal sintering is also the main reason for loss in activity. Micrographs of catalyst Pd-PAF-30-NH2 (Fig. 11(G, H)), which demonstrates worst stability among studied systems, have no noticeable differences from micrographs of catalyst before reactions. Average size of NPs is lower than for fresh sample (6.1 nm vs 5.4 nm). In case of Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst we expect that decline in activity is not related mainly to metal sintering and leaching, but to other reasons, like oligomerization products, as it was mentioned before. 3.3.5 Hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and 5-methylfurfural Pt and Pd catalysts were tested in the hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), which also belong to the family of furan compounds present in cellulosic bio-oil. The reactions were performed at 40 ℃ and 3 MPa H2 pressure for 2 hours in aqueous medium. Table 7 summarize the results of 5-HMF hydrogenation, the reaction scheme is presented in Fig. 12. All catalysts exhibit similar patterns as in the hydrogenation of furfural, except for the catalyst Pt-PAF-30. Thus, hydrogenation of 5-HMF on palladium catalysts occurs both on the furan ring and the carbonyl group. The main products were BHMTHF, HMTHF and DHMF with yields of 23–32 %. Side reaction products were HEXENONE and oligomers, which corresponds with results of FA hydrogenation and literature data [81,82]. Hydrogenation of 5-HMF on Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst proceeds in a manner maximally similar to that of furfural: the main products were BHMTHF with yield of 57 % and HMTHF with yield of 38 %. However, despite Pt-PAF-30 catalyst shows 94 % conversion in 5-HMF hydrogenation, main reaction product was 2,5-furandimethanol (DHMF) with 59 % selectivity, whereas the yield of the product of complete hydrogenation, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran (BHMTHF), was only 9 %. Nevertheless, the catalyst remained its activity in ring-opening reaction: so, reaction products contained 20 % of 1-hydroxy-4-hexen-2-one (HEXENONE), which may be formed as a result of hydroxyl group hydrogenation and further ring opening reaction [83]. Low activity in hydrogenation of furane ring in 5-HMF as well as low rate of HEXENONE hydrogenation to 1,2-HDOL can be attributed to more complex structure of these molecules and its derivatives compared to FA [84–86]. A small amount of by-products have also been detected, such as 5-methyl-2-furanmethanol (MHMF), 5-methyltetrahydro-2-furanmethanol (MHMTHF), 1,2-hexanediol (1,2-HDOL) and 5-HMF-based oligomers. The main product of 5-HMF hydrogenation on Pt-PAF-30-NH2 was also DHMF, however, overall conversion is lower than for Pt-PAF-30, which correlates with the results obtained previously for FA. Table 8 represents 5-MF hydrogenation results. Due to lack of literature data, 5-MF oligomers are proposed primarily based on GC-MS. Comparing to 5-HMF hydrogenation, there are two new products ( Fig. 13): 5-methyltetrahydrofurfural (5-MTHF) and 2,5-dimethyltetrahydrofuran (DMTHF). As expected, 5-MF undergoes same processes as other studied substrates: CO group hydrogenation, ring hydrogenation, hydrodeoxygenation and ring opening. The formation of HEXENONE is also observed as in the case of 5-HMF. Catalyst Pt-PAF-30-NH2 is characterized with 42 % conversion, main products are MHMF and DMTHF. Highest DMTHF yield (28 %) is achieved in the case of Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalyst. 4 Conclusions Noble metal catalysts based on porous aromatic frameworks were synthesized and tested in hydrogenation of furfural, 5-methylfurfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural at different conditions. The platinum catalysts Pt-PAF-30 and Pt-PAF-30-NH2 were active in furfural conversion into ring hydrogenation and ring-opening products due to the presence of electron-rich platinum. The Pt-PAF-30 catalyst possessed the highest activity in furfural hydrogenation to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. and the amount of side reaction products was significantly reduced when isopropanol was used as solvent. THFAL selectivity reached 83 % with 100 % FA conversion. Catalyst Pt-PAF-30-NH2 is characterized with lower selectivity to THFAL at full furfural conversion, however, it demonstrates selectivity to FAL up to 72 % at moderate reaction rates. Pt-PAF-30 proved to be more stable than amino-modified catalyst due to better nanoparticles encapsulation according to TEM. Hydrogenation of FA on palladium catalyst led to two main reaction products: THFA and THFAL. Various furfural-based oligomers were main side reaction products. Using isopropanol as solvent in hydrogenation of furfural on palladium catalyst modified with amino groups leads to 77 % yield of tetrahydrofurfural. Catalyst Pd-PAF-30 shows sufficiently good stability upon 5 reaction cycles. 5-HMF and 5-MF hydrogenation was performed on all studied catalysts and the formation of 1-hydroxy-4-hexen-2-one, product of furan ring opening, was discussed. To our knowledge, this compound has not yet been reported in topics related to furfural derivatives hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Platinum and palladium catalysts supported on two types of porous aromatic frameworks, PAF-30 and PAF-30-NH2 (modified with amino groups), were examined in furfural hydrogenation. The influence of temperature, reaction time and solvent on selectivity and activity of the catalysts was investigated. Using isopropanol as solvent and conducting experiments at 40 ℃ led to sufficient decrease of side products yields. According to TEM Pt-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2 catalysts are characterized with uniform particles distribution on support. Elemental analysis shows a difference in palladium content between Pd-PAF-30 and Pd-PAF-30-NH2: 4.6 % and 6.8 % respectively. Whereas platinum catalysts have both 5.4 % of metal. Catalyst Pt-PAF-30 was highly selective to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (83 % yield), whereas the catalyst Pd-PAF-30-NH2 exhibited unusually high selectivity towards tetrahydrofurfural (77 % yield). All studied catalysts were also tested in the hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and 5-methylfurfural, in these experiments up to 20 % yield of 1-hydroxy-4-hexen-2-one was observed.
